It's a massive oversimplification to say that the Anglican "mainstream" is anything. Anglicanism is the very definition of a broad church, there is no specifically Anglican catechism or confession of faith, the alliance of Christians within Anglicanism is as much an accident of history as a product of shared values. That said, for many Anglicans this very variety of belief and expression has led to greater tolerance of conflicting views. It's not even possible to pin down individual churches within the communion as being on one side or the other, though you could perhaps point to Nigeria, where the church is trying to out-hate extremist islam with regard to attitudes to women and homosexuals, as being most firmly on the reactionary side of things.
 
 It's certainly not sensible to portray this as north v south, one of the strongest proponents of liberal values in the Anglican Communion has been Archbishop Desmond Tutu, former archbishop of Cape Town, and fewer than half of African bishops attended the Faco conference. It is largely down to the personal views of Bishops, particularly in places like England where Bishops are appointed rather than elected. It's tempting with some, such as Michael Nazir-Ali, to attach some latent revenge motives to their views, given that the Bishop of Rochester was the evangelicals' favoured candidate to succeed George Carey, but that seems unchartiable.
